awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Memory-Efficient, Heterogeneity-Aware and Robust Architecture for Federated Intelligence on Edge Devices
awd_abstract_narration:
The recent trend of migrating computation from the centralized cloud to distributed edge devices is reshaping the landscape of today’s Internet, especially under the unprecedented challenges of the COVID19 pandemic. With privacy being a critical concern in data aggregation, Federated Learning emerges as a promising solution to such privacy-utility challenge. It pushes the computation towards consumer’s edge devices, where the data is generated. By exchanging statistical information, the participants perform collaborative learning in a distributed fashion. Unfortunately, the original design still faces new system-architectural challenges from limited memory, software/hardware heterogeneity, security and statistical diversity from different edge devices. The overarching goal of this CAREER project is to design, optimize and implement a memory-efficient, heterogeneity-aware and robust architecture for federated learning on consumer’s edge devices. In particular, it aims to: 1) remove the memory barriers of running the computational-intensive learning tasks; 2) resolve the software and hardware heterogeneity among various kinds of devices; 3) secure the information exchange and the machine learning backend. The research will provide a stack of solutions to address the urging needs in realizing collaborative intelligence on edge devices with computation/memory/energy-efficiencies, security and robustness. 

This research will address an urgent problem to bridge the gap between the vast data available from consumer’s edge devices and the rising interest of utilizing such private data to improve our wellbeing. The algorithms and tools developed in this CAREER project will lay the foundations to a plethora of new applications on massively distributed edge devices, as the essential elements for building a smart, connected and resilient community. The CAREER program will advance STEM education by developing new educational components related to machine learning, edge computing and security. This includes diverse outreach plans of cybersecurity summer camps, junior research symposium, high school instructor mentorship, coding competitions and the inclusion of underrepresented minority and women engineers. The potential use cases will be also explored with the collaborating industrial partners to enrich their business models.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
1. We have designed and implemented an asynchronous framework for energy conservation on battery-powered smartphones while running the federated learning tasks. Through a series of experiments on the ARM big.LITTLE SoC, we found that co-running the federated learning process on the little cores in the background with a foreground application on the big cores will save about 40-50% battery energy, with minimum performance impact. Based on this observation, we have designed an online optimization scheduler based on the Lyapunov control framework. One of the trade-off we have managed to handle is the gradient staleness while postponing the training sessions on edge devices with better co-running process. The Lyapunov control scheme maintains a job queue to balance such trade-offs. The paper is accepted by ICDCS 2022, C. Wang, et. al.,  Energy Minimization for Federated Asynchronous Learning on Battery-Powered Mobile Devices via Application Co-running, IEEE ICDCS 2022. 
  2. The journal version of the previous work has been accepted by IEEE Transactions on Mobile Computing. In this extension, we have accomplished the following: 1) mathematically proved that the convergence of scheme based on bounded staleness; 2) consider the slowdown model from hardware counters of contending the memory bandwidth; 3) conduct new experiments with the newest Snapdragon 888 SoCs. The work is published as: C. Wang and H. Wu, "Energy Optimization for Federated Learning on Consumer Mobile Devices With Asynchronous SGD and Application Co-Execution," in IEEE Transactions on Mobile Computing, doi: 10.1109/TMC.2024.3379236.        
  3. To achieve robustness against security flaws, we have designed a new detection scheme for neural networks to defend against adversarial examples, particularly in large-scale image retrieval systems based on the deep hashing scheme. The main technique is to design a fast and practical detection based on the last-level outputs and specific features of the adversarial examples by defining three complementing criterions: 1) hamming distance against untargeted attacks; 2) use the overfitting of the quantization loss to detect targeted attacks; 3) combine them with input inconsistency. We have also mathematically proved the hamming distance distributions from the untargeted attacks. In addition, we have extended the framework to consider white-box attackers who know the existence of the detector to enhance the defense scheme. The paper is published as Unsupervised Multi-Criteria Adversarial Detection in Deep Image Retrieval, Yanru Xiao, Cong Wang* and Xing Gao, EAI SecureComm, Hong Kong SAR, China, Oct. 2023
  4. This work was collaborated with Microsoft Research in Seattle on a new work to tackle biased distributional shifts and enhance the robustness against different data corruptions. We propose a new scheme from the perspective of the frequency domain. This is done by an Instance Multi-BatchNorm module to normalize training data with different distributions, that is able to balance the distributional tradeoffs from the frequency domains. We introduce another design using multi-band frequency domain augmentation to randomly augment training data in both high/low frequencies with a triplet training batch. The paper has been submitted to ECCV24. 
  5. In addition, we have made a few new explorations of heterogeneous federated model fusion: 1) by utilizing PGD attack as an adversarial proxy to estimate boundary dynamics, we re-design the distillation process to attend to samples with higher entropy. This work has been submitted to AAAI25; 2) We transform the centralized heterogeneous model fusion into a decentralized model fusion and prove its convergence. We further crafted a new online learning mechanism to optimize peer-to-peer distillation with contextual bandits. This work has been submitted to INFOCOM25.
  6. Along the line of the original proposal, we have design a new pipeline planner to enable multi-DNN inference on heterogeneous processors of CPU, GPU and NPU. The planner has polynomial-time run-time with a manageable two-stage processing procedure. The entire system is implemented on 3 typical SoCs from Snapdragon series to Kirin 990. This work has been submitted to INFOCOM25 as well.
  7. We have explored a new type of attack called latency attack for object detectors against resource-constrained edge devices. Our main contribution is to propose a hardware-adaptive, background-attentative defense against these attacks. We have leveraged a roofline model to quantify the hardware processing capacity of the edge devices against these attacks and connect it with the adversarial training process. This work has been submitted to AAAI25 as well.
